title: How can a normal helmet incorporate heads up display (HUD) technology? - Quora

response.answer_text: I am certain most of the people might be aware of the brand called Skully. They made a first-ever proper prototype by turning a motorcycle helmet into the likes of many aviation type HUD but with the protection of a full-face helmet. The answers below are great, but they are not ordinary helmets and I doubt if any normal people would succeed getting their hands on a thousand dollar technology used by the military for state-of-the-art combat machines. So lets back a bit and focus on the actual question which I am assuming is “normal helmet” = “street helmet” for motorcycle riding. With that in mind, here is what I think… Certainly, a regular street helmet can be kitted with the HUD unit to stream information from an external source like a mobile phone or on-board computers of a motorcycle. Now the challenge ahead of such an engineering feat is always the “size limitation.” It is also the answer to this question. A normal helmet can incorporate HUD when more space is available. If you looked up Skully, you’ll notice it appears slightly different from a regular street helmet. It is bigger and elongated. That’s because all the complex hardware and power unit had to be shrunk to fit into a street-legal helmet. Electronics in an aviation-grade helmet was always possible because of space availability and lack of size regulation. Remember, a pilot’s helmet is not built for crash protection. So the liner is thin making more room for mounting HUD and other electronics. The power to the system is provided by the aircraft. A motorcycle helmet has the size and weight regulations to comply with before it’s made street legal. So manufacturers must play within tolerances without compromising the wearer’s safety. This is one reason why this is technology is still on the anvil. From the safety perspective, I think it could get in the way of safe riding because a new user must train and adapt to avoid getting distracted by the information populated on the display. While pilots train thousands of hours to consume HUD information and perform flight operations without risk, an average motorist may not have the dexterity to read basic information and avoid traffic hazards at the same time. Therefore, due to the enormous learning curve and overall complexity, it isn’t in anyone’s interest to build a practical helmet with HUD. In theory, it saves the effort to look up information on the go. With the improvement in technology, it's possible to have a compact unit with better battery performance. But until that happens, we can continue hoping it could someday become a reality.

Modern display devices can be small and light while remaining bright - the brightness is important as a lot of the image brightness is lost in the combiner, since the pilot must be able to see through it very well. Small and light means they are not too large a burden on the pilot’s neck. Optical waveguides can be used to take the display image from the collimating lens system (next to the display) to the combiner (in front of the pilot’s eye(s). Or mirrors can be used.
